course_metadata.notes: Highly technical coastal ultra with constant punchy climbs, exposure, and quad damage. Cornwall's toughest 40km.
course_metadata.calibration_source: Arc 2025 actual result: 4:23 at fitness 1.15, 4-8°C conditions, respiratory incident at 15km

temperature_variation.notes: February race. Cold start, moderate warming. Wind chill significant on exposed sections.

wind_exposure_sections: Cliff tops have 20-40 km/h winds typical
Some shelter in valleys but brief

seasonal_considerations.february: Cold, wet, stormy. Respiratory risk for asthma. Typical Arc conditions.

technicality.notes: Extremely technical. Wet rocks, mud, constant transitions. One of UK's most technical short ultras.

runnability.notes: Constant transitions. Very little sustained rhythm. Up/down/up/down for 40km.

foot_hazards.notes: Wet rocks and mud create constant slip hazard. Ankle rolls common on rocky sections.

climb_blocks.notes: Repeated steep climbs drive early fatigue accumulation. No time to recover between efforts.

descent_blocks.notes: Severe eccentric load. High quad and foot fatigue. Technical rocky descents require constant focus.

aid_stations.name: Start - Bude
aid_stations.crew_instructions: Send off only. No crew access after start.
aid_stations.notes: Start line at Bude. Cold morning, warm up thoroughly.

aid_stations.name: CP1 - Widemouth Bay
aid_stations.notes: First checkpoint. Keep moving. Still in vulnerable respiratory zone (km 3-25).

aid_stations.name: CP2 - Crackington Haven
aid_stations.crew_instructions: Drop bag available. Have backup inhaler ready. Warm drink if cold. Check for blisters.
aid_stations.notes: Major checkpoint. Crew access. Just past km 15 respiratory incident risk zone. Assess state carefully.

aid_stations.name: CP3 - Boscastle
aid_stations.notes: No crew. Quick stop. Over halfway - mental boost point.

aid_stations.name: CP4 - Tintagel
aid_stations.notes: Last checkpoint. 8km remaining. Time to push through fatigue.

aid_stations.name: Finish - Trebarwith Strand
aid_stations.crew_instructions: Recovery gear ready. Warm clothes, food.
aid_stations.notes: Finish at beach. Celebrate and recover.

aid_station_model.notes: Stops are short but cognitively costly in poor weather. Crew stops at CP2 tend to be longer (60-90s vs 45-60s). Keep discipline - timer at each stop.

navigation.notes: Well-marked South West Coast Path. Navigation straightforward - following coastline. Focus on footing, not navigation.

key_segments.name: Start to Widemouth (0-8.5km)
key_segments.description: First coastal section. Establishing rhythm on technical terrain.
key_segments.strategy_notes: CONSERVATIVE START. Stay below HR threshold. Warm up thoroughly. This is where 2025 incident nearly happened.

key_segments.name: Widemouth to Crackington (8.5-16km)
key_segments.description: Technical coastal path with constant elevation changes.
key_segments.strategy_notes: RESPIRATORY CRITICAL ZONE. If any breathing issues, slow immediately. Carry inhaler. Power hike steeper sections.

key_segments.name: Crackington to Boscastle (16-24.5km)
key_segments.description: Midpoint push. Fatigue accumulating but past respiratory danger.
key_segments.strategy_notes: Past respiratory danger. Focus on fueling and quad preservation. Power hike aggressively on climbs.

key_segments.name: Boscastle to Tintagel (24.5-32km)
key_segments.strategy_notes: Survival mode. Just keep moving forward. Every step counts. Use caffeine if needed.

key_segments.name: Tintagel to Finish (32-40km)
key_segments.strategy_notes: 8km is nothing. You've got this. Push through pain. Finish is close.

fatigue_model.notes: Early fatigue onset despite short distance. Constant transitions and eccentric load accelerate fatigue.

field_effects.notes: You slightly outperform field on technical terrain and when weather deteriorates. Your strengths play here.

dnf_risk_factors.notes: Respiratory incident is highest DNF risk. Cold + effort in km 3-25 zone. Also quad damage in final 10km.

athlete_specific_targets.notes: Validated: 2025 result was 4:23 at fitness 1.15 with respiratory incident at 15km. Without incident, likely 4:15-4:18.

sanity_checks: Arc pace should be ~5.5–6.5 km/h average (validated: 4:23 = 9.1 km/h average - FASTER than expected due to runnable sections)
Fatigue must accumulate earlier than Chianti despite shorter distance
Downhill damage should be dominant limiter in final 10km
Respiratory risk peaks km 3-25, especially around km 15

race_strategy.pacing_approach: CONSERVATIVE first 15km (respiratory danger zone). Target 6:30-7:00 min/km early even if you feel great. After CP2 (16km), can push harder if breathing is clear. Expect 10-15% slowdown after 25km due to quad fatigue.
race_strategy.nutrition_plan: 60g carbs/hour starting at hour 1. Water + electrolytes every 30min. First caffeine at 2.5-3 hours (around Boscastle). Save big caffeine dose (200mg) for final 10km if struggling.
race_strategy.mental_preparation: Embrace the suffering - Arc is supposed to hurt. Every runner is struggling. Your technical strength and descending ability are weapons here. The constant up/down is mentally tough but you're built for this. If respiratory incident occurs, SLOW DOWN immediately - don't push through.
race_strategy.crew_strategy: Only crew access at CP2 (16km). Have backup inhaler ready. Quick turnaround - 60s target. Pre-pack next section nutrition. Warm drink if cold/wet. Blister check. Morale boost then send off.

calibration_notes.version_1_0: Initial profile based on course description and general Arc results.

actual_result_2025.notes: Faster than initial estimates. Course is more runnable than expected. Respiratory incident validated vulnerable zone model. Without incident, projected 4:15-4:18.

adjustments_made.technical_multiplier: Improved from 0.90 to 0.92 (course faster than expected)
adjustments_made.field_effects: Added multipliers for technical (1.02) and weather (1.04) - you outperform field
adjustments_made.fatigue_model: Confirmed early onset at 22km despite 40km total
adjustments_made.respiratory_model: Validated km 3-25 vulnerable zone, particularly km 15
